CatDescriptText: Mr. Clinton Tench, shipper, North Side and Miss Agnes Dye, student, Sewickley, were part of the Pittsburghers Speak Up column published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, March 4, 1961, pg. 7 with question "Who do you think is largely responsible for Negro topflight entertainers being denied the chance to headline the Grade A television shows--the sponsors, the advertising agencies, or the general public?" Mr. Tench's answer reads: "I think that it's the general public and mainly Negroes who do not stick together and who are afraid to go for what they want..."  Miss Dye's answer reads: "I think that the sponsors are responsible, and also the advertising men might be afraid of sponsoring a Negro on the show, because of a fear that they will lose a lot of their trade."
TitMainTitle: Two frames: Portrait of Clinton Tench wearing moustache and dark long sleeved button down shirt, standing in front of window with reflected Baum Building and "Decorator" signs, Liberty Avenue, Downtown; Portrait of Agnes Dye wearing dark hat with brooch and dark coat with embroidered stripes on lapels, standing in front of Clark Building, Liberty Avenue, Downtown
